summary: The code defines functions to iterate over a table of strings, applying a function to each sub-table and concatenating non-empty elements into a single string for further processing or analysis. It also reads data from multiple commands using io.popen and writes it into a candidate list.

details.comment: This code defines two functions, "map_all" and "appendnow", which iterate over a table of strings. The map_all function applies a given function to each sub-table within the main table, and the appendnow function concatenates non-empty string elements from each sub-table into a single string. These appended strings are then added to another table called Table0. The code concludes by demonstrating an example usage of these functions on the original Table.
details.content:
Table={
	[1]={"pdf","document","doc",""},
	[2]={"reader","conver","format",""},
	[3]={"txt","text","word",""}
}
--shorter, and more common is better.
--not even the whole word.
Table0={}
spliter="---------fuckyou---------"
function map_all (fcn, tab, idx, ...)
    if idx < 1 then
	    --count of the list.
	--print("--spliter--")
	-- this is the print-them-all function.
        fcn(...)
	--print("--spliter--")
	-- it is appending the thing on the back of argument list.
    else
        local t = tab[idx]
	-- length minus one.
        for i = 1, #t do
		--print("--spliter0--")
		map_all(fcn, tab, idx-1, t[i], ...) 
		--print("--spliter0--")
	end
    end
end
function appendnow(...)
	local shit=""
	for fuck,nothing in ipairs({...}) do
		if nothing~=""  then
			shit=shit.." \""..nothing.."\""
		end
	end
	if shit~="" then
		Table0[#Table0+1]=shit
	end
end
map_all(appendnow, Table, #Table)
--[[for x ,v in ipairs(Table0) do
	print(v)
end]]
handle={}                                  for key,value in ipairs(Table0) do
	command ="apt-cache search"..value

details.comment: The code opens and reads a command using io.popen, adds it to the handle table, and then iterates through the handle table to read the content, close the file handles, and write the result. The purpose seems to be reading data from multiple commands and writing it into a candidate list, potentially for further processing or analysis.
details.content:
-- no trailing space.
--psudocode above.     
	handle[#handle+1]= io.popen(command)       --is it threaded?                  
end   
for key,value in pairs(handle) do
	result = handle[key]:read("*a")
	handle[key]:close()                        -- use local instead of using some functions.
--	print (result)
	print(Table0[key])
	print(spliter)
	io.write(result)
	print(spliter)
end
--anything is global here.
